title: How did the tiny Baltic states manage to separate from the USSR? - Quora

response.answer_text: The Baltic states may be smaller is size but not small by importance while in USSR. The 3 Baltic republics were the Westernmost in Soviet Union geogaphically, and the only republics out of 15 USSR republics that already have experienced being independent capitalistic countries prior to Soviet occupation. This is why they were always looking back to freedom, from the first day of being included into USSR. Baltic states were more advanced economicaly and had higher salaries than USSR average, especially Estonia. They could also offer to ex-USSR tourists something than no other Soviet republic could: the European athmosphere, as much as it was allowed and possible during those times. Saying that Baltics states did not separated being poorest, devastated, ran down or messed up…they were in good shape (on the USSR level of course) right before the big events started. They were not running from hunger, they were running into their new reality - getting their country back. Baltic states had some degree of respect while in USSR. It was cool to be from there or to visit over there. When wanted to exit USSR I am sure this claim was taken on more serious allegations than let say if something like Mordva Republic somewhere in Ural would claim independece (no one would take it seriously). Baltic states, with Lithuania in the lead, separated pretty peacefully (with only 14 dead in Lithuania and 0 dead in Latvia) thanks to enormous support from the World. Each of those nations also had quite substantial diasporha in Western countries and USA. There are around 1 mln people world wide that relate to Lithuanian nationality outside country, many of them wealthy people who left the country when Communism was established. These people helped rebuilding new Baltic states, opening businesses and promoting them to the world. Progress was so great and fast that just in 15 years after separation all 3 Baltic states were ready to be accepted to common market - European Union, where some Eastern European countries that were NOT part of USSR cannot enter until now… P.s. Everyone likes to call Baltic “tiny” but they are maybe not huge but not just tiny. Lithuania and Latvia each is bigger by land mass than: Netherldand, Belgium, Switzerland, Denmark, Croatia, Israel, Slovakia, Georgia and nearly the size of Ireland, Czech Republic, Scotland or Austria (maybe 10% smaller than the last two). But why no one ever (EVER!) calls those mentioned countries as “tiny”? But they ALWAYS do that with Baltics which often are larger than many of European countries. When you meet someone from Holland you just drop the fact about size, no one cares - you never say to a Ducth “Oh my God your country is tiny” - and Holland is about half size of Lithuania. 😀 Just a though.

Lithuania (11 March 1990) and Georgia (9 April 1991) were the only states that proclaimed independence fully in the times when Gorbachev was a full-fledged President of USSR (in other words before 19 August 1991). Now the quote from 25 Years Ago, Gorbachev’s Economic Blockade Failed to Keep Lithuania in the USSR (it is about events right after 11 march 1990) The Lithuanians refused to back down and so Moscow issued an ultimatum on April 13: drop all talk about independence or face economic sanctions in the form of a blockade. Again, Vilnius did not retreat, and the Soviet government introduced sanctions against Lithuania as of April 18. The Soviet blockade of a republic Moscow viewed as being part of the USSR began with restrictions on the supply of oil and gas to Lithuania, then other products and raw materials were added. Not surprisingly, prices for these goods shot up and forced the Lithuanian Supreme Council to introduce rationing. Gorbachev then introduced a naval blockade there. But the Soviet blockade quickly backfired on Moscow, not only because it limited the Soviet government’s ability to supply the non-contiguous Kaliningrad Region but also because Lithuania stopped providing electricity to Soviet army units on its territory and sending goods to the USSR. Nonetheless, the Soviet sanctions bit and bit hard, and on May 23, the Lithuanian Supreme Council appealed to the international community to consider what Moscow as doing as “economic aggression” and thus a measure that was equivalent to “any other form of aggression” against a foreign state. Failing to get the support it hoped for, the Lithuanian Supreme Council five weeks later, on June 29, declared a 100-day moratorium on its March 11 declaration and called for negotiations with Moscow. These talks led to nothing, and on December 28, the Council reinstated the March 11 declaration on the restoration of independence. That action led Gorbachev to send additional Soviet troops to Lithuania — there were already 100,000 there –to enforce the Soviet draft. But in fact, it was an act of intimidation. Two weeks later, on January 13, 1991, those troops fired on peaceful demonstrators at the Vilnius TV tower, killing 13 and ending any chance that Lithuania would remain within the USSR. And the most interesting thing happened next to this January Events (Lithuania) - Wikipedia - on Manezhnaya Square, Moscow - Wikipedia on Sunday 20 January 1991 happened the biggest rally in all Russian history. It was a rally against the use of force against Lithuania (in fact in support of independence of Lithuania) - according to Andrey Piontkovsky - Wikipedia about half a million people participated. Below is a shot of this rally  And the leadership of Russian SFSR (headed by Boris Yeltsin) supported Lithuania and of course Estonia, Latvia, Georgia, Armenia, Moldova and, what is the most important, Ukraine were on Lithuania’s side so Kremlin couldnt oppose them. Then on 9 February 1991 Lithuanian independence referendum - Wikipedia was held, on 3 March 1991 Latvian independence and democracy referendum - Wikipedia and 1991 Estonian independence referendum - Wikipedia on 31 March 1991 Georgian independence referendum - Wikipedia from July Ukraine stopped to pay in the budget of USSR so USSR was slowly dying … then on 19 August an attempt to save USSR was made 1991 Soviet coup d'état attempt - Wikipedia and after its fail USSR died quickly

They were supported by Russian President Boris Yeltsin. Yeltsin wanted to dismember the USSR because he believed the other republics were taking advantage of Russia's resources. By the dismantling of the USSR Gorbachev would have run out of office and Yeltsin would have become head of state. So Yeltsin supported the Baltic struggle for independence. A bas-relief of Yeltsin is on display in Tallinn:  Opinion: The Yeltsin Monument and National Arrogance ”In his clash with the Soviet leader Gorbachev, Yeltsin stressed the sovereignty of Union republics. Their aspirations for independence and their increasing importance as a result tempted Yeltsin to run for president of Russia, as well as to claim that Russia would be better off without the Soviet Union and funding other Union republics. Supporting the independence aspirations of the Baltic countries was one of the few opportunities for Yeltsin to undermine Gorbachev’s reputation in the West and form new ties with the leaders in Western countries, especially leading politicians in the US, who generally saw Gorbachev’s rule as the best possible scenario.” Revelations on the Restoration of Independence

Because Yeltsin was fighting against Gorbi for the power. The three B. republics were only a mean in that struggle. Besides, already in late 1990s their sea ports were already used to smuggle raw resources from Russia. That export was organized and controlled by people close to Yeltsin. Later Latvian banks specifically became money laundries for Russian dirty money. There is a good joke about the Uncatchable Joe. “Is he indeed so uncatchable nobody can seize him?” - “Come on! Nobody just gives a f*ck”. That's the actual way the separation of the three B. states occured.

Sooner or later they will create a myth that they bravely defeated the USSR. In reality, they were allowed to split in existing borders and without any condition after “big brothers” agreed to finish the USSR in 1991  Moreover, as a time witness, I remember well how the Russian public in Moscow supported the Baltics independence in 1991. We knew we do not belong together and did naively hope that they will appreciate our generosity and after the splitting, we will establish good neighbor relationships.

All this story about supposed “help” of foreign agents is exegerated. There is no agent that could persuade 2 million people to stand hand in hand in Baltic Way - Wikipedia, basically, from spring/ summer of 1988 the Baltic States formed a civil society movement structures (Sąjūdis / Tautas Fronte / Rahvarinne, estonians also had Congress of Estonia - Wikipedia). They were both basing their activities on ecological civil protest, continuity from interwar years, support from Russia (Yakovlev etc), experience from Poland / Solidarnosc and own participation / win in first democratic elections.  P.S> I suggest you to read this amusing article As the USSR Collapsed: A CIA Officer in Lithuania

They could not have done this without the desire of the central government, which did not impede the real separation process, but officially protested. They acted in such a way as set against theyrself the population of these republics and other people in the USSR (both supporters and opponents of the separation of the Baltic states).

Civil disobedience.Stryke and public protests. Solidarity movement in Poland invented this path for change.The most important element was including existing power structures in transition.This way elites had nothing to loose but gain more independence from central Soviet system. But of course they had a lot of supports from forigner intelligent agencies.

The same way all weaker areas breakaway from their powerful masters-they do it when the master is busy doing other things. For the US Britain was busy fighting the French. For the Baltic States the Soviet Union was busy imploding. Your best bet is to scamper away when the Big Guy isn’t looking.
Please, read this: Singing Revolution - Wikipedia
Basically it comes down to the Russians no longer wanting to spend their military forces to enforce soviet rule in the satellite states.
The Union republics did have the right of secession under the Soviet constitution. (Though the Baltics did not wait and quit without a referendum like the others had)
